response.answer_text: I like Nagarajan's response, but I’m going to assume a more mundane approach. I attended recently the conference that Bessel van der Kolk organizes every year. This year they offered several lectures on Self. I was really eager to hear the latest on the discoveries on self since it’s becoming obvious that trauma shatters the sense of self, and therefore, it’s essential to understand how to repair it. To my surprise, instead of talking about perception, they talked about “senses.” That’s why I jumped into responding to your question. The most interesting take from the conference is that using the “internal” senses can help us feeling ourselves, connecting with a sense of us, on how we work, and how we exist. Those senses are mainly proprioception (perception or awareness of the position and movement of the body), and interception (helps understand and feel what's going on inside your body). Proprioception refers to information coming to the brain about the position and movement of the body and is essential for coordinated movement. Proprioception includes the sense of position and movement of our limbs, the senses of muscle force and effort, and the sense of balance. In addition to knowing where our limbs are in space, at least two other sensations contribute to our physical self-awareness: a sense of force and a sense of effort or heaviness. Conscious proprioceptive awareness of reflex postural preparedness may give rise to pleasant experiences of stability, readiness, and self-efficacy, or unpleasant feelings of lack of confidence and anxiety. There are a number of serious, debilitating conditions associated with disturbances to the body image. These include eating disorders such as anorexia nervosa; conditions in which the patient denies that a part of their body actually belongs to them; and out-of-body experiences, where the patient believes that their body is no longer under their own control. Indeed, our very sense of self is believed to be generated in association with the central processing of proprioceptive information (Gandevia et al, 2016). Interoception is a sense that provides information about the internal condition of our body—how our body is feeling on the inside. At the most basic level, interoception allows us to answer the question, “how do I feel?” at any given moment which prompts us to take action based on the body signals we notice. Interoception allows us to experience many body sensations such as a growling stomach, dry mouth, tense muscles, or racing heart. Awareness of these body sensations enables us to experience essential emotions such as hunger, fullness, thirst, pain, body temperature, need for the bathroom, sexual arousal, relaxation, anxiety, sadness, frustration, and safety (Mahler, 2017). Interoception encompasses the brain's process of integrating signals relayed from the body into specific subregions—like the brainstem, thalamus, insula, somatosensory, and anterior cingulate cortex —allowing for a nuanced representation of the physiological state of the body. This is important for maintaining homeostatic conditions in the body and, potentially, aiding in self-awareness. Interoception has been proposed as key to resilience as the accurate processing of internal bodily states promotes a quick restoration of homeostatic balance (Hasse et al, 2016), and as an aid in developing a stronger sense of self. The increased awareness of this sense has to do with “biofeedback” where the ability of a person to gain control over autonomic functions is a method of treatment for varying conditions, especially trauma. Since interoception was considered important, now definitions include widens the concept to encompass “the skin and all that is underneath the skin” and the perception and function of bodily activity to more fully understand psychosomatic processes.“ The physiological status of all tissues in the body and its mapping onto the brain provides an individual with subjective feeling states which are critical for human emotion and self-awareness. Emotions are actually perceived by this sense. Attention to interoceptive and proprioceptive experience may be more effective in handling stress and emotional dysregulation than attention to ideas and thoughts alone, because bodily experience allows more direct access to stages of response —like reflexive noticing and orienting to the stimulus, preparation, and execution of response. In this case, noticing our internal state helps using better defenses than the ones that get triggered automatically if we don’t notice; they also serve the function of connecting our frontal lobes with more sensory information, giving us more control over emotional responses; and lastly, they give us a better sense of who we are, helping to develop a better perception of how our reactions are connected to our body functions. Stephen Porges has added up another sense he calls Neuroception. Neuroception is the capacity to distinguish whether situations or people are safe, dangerous, or life-threatening. It explains why a baby coos at a caregiver but cries at a stranger, or why a toddler enjoys a parent’s embrace but views a hug from a stranger an assault. Porges states that faulty neuroception might lie at the root of several psychiatric disorders, including autism, schizophrenia, anxiety disorders, depression, and Reactive Attachment Disorder, and that it’s essential in the studies of trauma. All these senses provide useful information about or emotional state, and therefore it’s used in the somatic modalities that are trauma-informed like Somatic Experiencing, or EMDR. To answer your question, YES, we can sense ourselves by using our internal senses, and not only the external ones. As we sense our bodies and our physiological changes, we can perceive the state of our Self.

The eye of the eye, the ear of the ear, the nose of the nose, the tongue of the tongue, the skin of the skin and the mind of the mind is unknowable and incomprehensible. However this mysterious LIGHT hidden in the background and the foreground of all of our perceptions is ALIVE and INTELLIGENT. This LIGHT is self-luminous, self-evident, non-local and non-temporal. This LIGHT is impersonal, in that IT does not belong to anybody, but is the most intimate REALITY to all living beings. This LIGHT is very intimate and just like the eye can see everything else but it can never see itself, this LIGHT has no way of knowing itself but all that IT can say is “I perceive this cosmos and therefore I AM!”. This is the reason why most humans cannot “see” this LIGHT even though IT is sitting right on their noses. This LIGHT can only be intuited by the eye of wisdom of one who is awakened.

Our five senses fail to perceive many realities, such as Virtue, Goodness, Courage, Honesty and the way toward Justice. Anything transcendental is invisible by the five senses. That includes the Self. The dogmatic Empiricist will conclude on that basis that the Self doesn’t exist, because it cannot be placed under a microscope to examine its visible properties. Yet, as Rene Descartes showed (1650), the Self is the most undeniable fact of our existence. Even though the Self is invisible to the five senses — many other Realities are also invisible to the five senses.

The self is the perciever. Thats it.. full stop , everything else beyond this point as the observable universe is a creation of that self. The mind, the body the stars the planet's are all made of the same fundamental 5 elements that have created all of existence for the purpose of sensing it as a temporal reality. And so that why science, philosophy and materialist will go on into infinity seeking its point of origin.. and so will never ever.. ever find it. But because we think in the mind and work through a body we assume that is how it must be, while in truth it (as everything we think we are) is just an evolved construct of self.. It.. the “I am”.. is right here, the one reading this is the self and as is the self who is thumb typing it in, all just from a different vantage point here to remind you of these things.. the truth is always simple, only man complicates it. Rest in it, and know. L&L

‘self’ is created by an organization of the senses into language. ‘self’ exists only as language. when you’re ‘being yourself’ you’re not able to be a not-self’. that means that it’s a linear, only in one direction, assertion. look how we use the word: “i scared myself.” and, “i played with myself”. these have physical connections with reality. but, “i can’t find myself”. or, “i want to be more than myself”. these seem to connect with something real, but the emotion felt is the engine and destination in this kind of drive towards knowledge.

Sense perceives self until it doesn't. While I, as life feel I am an I in the body, then that I which is a veil or sensed split as life believes it is feeling itself. When, by grace the dissolution of a sense of an I in the body is no longer here, perception is simply perception… Sensation… not two happening…
Sure. We all have a sense of self. As Deanna Troi said in “Star Trek,” “when you ask yourself a question, who are you talking to?”
